bibl.title: Letter from Bertha L. Lyons to Philip Showalter Hench, March 22, 1948

div1.p: Lyons clears up some confusion about which items she wanted Hench to send for the Hall of Fame program. Howard will be invited to the ceremony, and she hopes he can come. She regrets that Hench will be unable to attend.

div1.head: Letter from Bertha L. Lyons to Philip Showalter Hench, March 22, 1948
div1.opener:
Every American is a shareholder in the Hall of Fame
HALL OF FAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY
I MADISON AVENUE · NEW YORK IO, N. Y.
Telephone: MURRAY HILL 3-4469
22 March 1948
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
Thank you very much for your helpful letter of
March 19. I failed to make myself thoroughly understood in my
letter to you of March 12 indicating items which I wished re-
produced. If you will refer to that letter, you will find that
the first items which I requested were those indicated in your
letter of February 23, and the numbers used were the numbers which
you had indicated in your suggested list. When I referred to
the other documents wanted, I definitely referred to your general
list and thus used the numbers indicated on that list. Items 14
and 15 therefore are not the collective works of Finlay, and the
Senate document No. 61. Item 14 in your letter of February 23 is
a reproduction of part of one of Walter Reed's letters to his
wife written during the excitement of the experiments. No. 15
is a reproduction of a part of one of Reed's early letters to
his fiance before they were married, in which he expressed,
even then, early in life, an earnest desire to help humanity.
You are right, of course, I could not use the collective works
of Finlay, nor the Senate document No. 61, and frankly, for the
purpose of this ceremony, we are not too interested in Finlay's
collective works, great as was his part in the experiments in
yellow fever. Item No. 25 may be eliminated entirely. I fear,
since it is as technical as we both thought it was, it would not
serve our particular purpose.

It was very good of you to write to Dr. Clemons,
head of the library at the University of Virginia, asking him
to make photostats and photographs of the items indicated in
your letter of March 19.

I have already written to General Kean in an effort
to get copies of such material as he may have on hand, and I shall
write him again today specifically asking for the letters of
Dr. Welch and General Wood. I shall also ask him for a copy of
the photograph of the birthplace. We too have a post card showing
the birthplace, which is rather inadequate, and I am hoping very
much that he will be able to furnish us with a better copy or
tell us where we may procure one.

I am happy to know that the Metropolitan Life
Insurance Company has some early photographs of Walter Reed,
and since we are in the Metropolitan Life Building, I shall
telephone to that department and see what I can “round up.”
I have had communication with that department once before
and have given them some material from time to time, so that
I feel certain they will be happy to turn over whatever they
have to us for this occasion.

Regarding Dr. Howard, thank you for suggesting
him and his daughter for invitations. As a matter of fact,
Mr. Gamache of The American Foundation for Tropical Medicine, Inc.,
who is making up our invitations lists for us, had already given us
Dr. Howard's address. We shall, of course, include his daughter
as you suggest. We hope very much that Dr. Howard will find it
possible to attend the ceremony. Perhaps his daughter has a car
and if it is a good day could drive him down without too much
difficulty.

You are perfectly right. I am assembling
a great deal more material than I could possibly use in our
program, but I must see what there is and try to get the most
interesting things possible.

Again, I hesitate to put you to all this trouble
of getting the material together for us, but since it is in
your possession, I do not know what else we could do in the
matter, except say, thanks loud and deep to you.

I regret more than I can tell you that you and
Mrs. Hench will not be able to attend the ceremony, for I know
that a number of your colleagues have been looking forward to
seeing you that day, particularly Dr. Salisbury; Dr. Meleney,
and many others, to say nothing of Dr. Angell and myself.

With kind regards, and again with deepest
appreciation, believe me
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, Bertha L. Lyons
Assistant to the Director BLL:yz
Dr. Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
